What an honour and privilege to be sitting in the Circle with such amazing peoples-our Elders and Knowledge Holders-as we discuss Treaties.
The Royal Proclamation of 1763 laid the foundation for future treaty negotiations & it helped to define relations. ~ Ken Young, Cree Lawyer.
"We don't need to ask for what we already know what is right. But we must always listen." ~ Mel Chartrand
Treaties were always here even before European contact. Our people understood what relationships were & how we interact/share w each other.
Relationships is all about balance, being patient and to listen with an open heart. ~ Mel Chartrand
"No deserves to be poor, and the relationships we have with each other are grounded in the Treaties." ~ Ken Young, Cree Lawyer
"The greatest gift I have is not to be angry." ~ Elder Charlie Nelson.  I love this.
We must plan for our future - our children.  This is all what matters.  Let us always remember this.
Elder Margaret Lavallee explains we have take back what is rightly ours - our connections to the spirit and ceremonies.
There are many different types and definitions of relationships - social, economic and political.  Each have a direct impact on our lives.
Tell the truth and share the truth.  we are beautiful people. Be proud. - Dave Cochrane Jr., Elder.
Everyone belongs to the Earth.  No one owns it. Treaties help to define the relationships & how we share the resources.
Let us share and be friends.  It can be that simple.
It is a great day at UM as Elders & Knowledge Holders have joined us as part of #IAW for a dialogue on Relationships. http://t.co/H0p9O1h6Pj
UM Indigenous Science Students helping to make a difference in the Faculty of Science. @umanitoba -  http://t.co/fdoMVz8LHb
Sharon Parenteau explains to be Metis one needs to accepted by the Metis community and MUST have Metis Scrip.
Love ourselves and in turn we can love others.
The common connection between Metis Scrip & Treaty - is the connection to the land & the resources within it.
Sharon Parenteau, Louis Riel Institute, & Elder Norman Meade, shares their knowledge with us. http://t.co/ORZepWjqGb
What does Metis Scrip mean?  Today we are looking into this question as part of the week long sessions for Indigenous Awareness Week.
#IAW at UM continues with a session on Metis scrip! http://t.co/HpGgvq4w6z
Listen, learn, and only then we can move forward together.

Architects have a responsibility to learn about Indigenous history & relationships and how it relates our spaces & places.
